conversation.content: So, um, you've been fixing bikes here for, like, how long now, I mean, in this shop?
Oh well, going on twelve years [very loudly] now! Started as an apprentice, you know, when I was nineteen, and honestly, my hands have been covered in grease ever since.
Must be tough on your back, all that bending over bikes.
Yeah, my back is [stuttering] sh-shot to hell, honestly, and my knees creak like an old door, but that's the trade for you—bodies aren't meant to be bent over bike frames eight hours a day.
Do you [shy] ever think about doing something else?

Sometimes, uhh, when it's raining and my arthritis acts up, I mean, I dream about a desk job, but honestly, the thought of being stuck inside all day without actually, like, making something with my hands—that'd kill me faster than the back pain.
What's the worst repair you've had to deal with?
Had this kid bring in a bike last week that looked like it went through a wood chipper—every single component was destroyed, took me fourteen hours over three days just to make it rideable again.
That's, err, a lot of work for one bike, you know, was it even, basically, worth it?
Financially? Hell no, but, umm, the look on that kid's face when he saw it working again, I guess, that's why I keep doing this even when my body, like, screams at me to stop.
Your hands look pretty beat up.

Oh these things? [laugh loudly] They're basically just scar tissue and calluses at this point! Cut myself on chainrings so many times I don't even feel it anymore, just notice the blood on the components.
That's [cheerful] kind of hardcore actually!
It's not [apologetic] glamorous or anything, just years of small injuries adding up—broken fingers from wrenches slipping, burns from welding, cuts from cables, all part of the territory really.
But you're [happy] still here, still working.
Yeah, I'm still [slowly] here, still turning wrenches, still coming home smelling like chain lube and degreaser, still waking up at five-thirty with hands too stiff to make coffee properly.
Sounds, well, exhausting, really, like, how do you, actually, keep going every day?

Coffee, ibuprofen, and stubbornness mostly, but err, also because every bike that rolls out of here, you know, is someone's freedom, their transportation, basically their joy—that matters even when everything hurts.
Do you, hmm, regret choosing this, I mean, this life, sort of?

Some mornings when I can barely straighten my fingers, yeah, but then I get under a bike and everything makes sense again—these machines need someone who understands them, and that someone happens to be me.
